Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: : Efficient and Powerful Generator with Piezoelectric Nanomaterials

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research Objectives and Approaches
The objective of this research is to harvest otherwise wasted mechanical energy and produce renewable electricity with piezoelectric nanomaterials. The approach is focused on the significant factors in the energy conversion at the nanoscale with the development of a 3-dimensional energy harvester, which capitalizes on the significant advantages in material properties and dynamics that nanowires offer.

Intellectual Merit
The research will lead to greater understanding of energy conversion in piezoelectric zinc oxide and barium titanate nanowires through a 3-dimensional generator based on laterally aligned nanowire arrays. Calculations show that a 3-dimensional generator will produce orders-of-magnitude greater power than current 2-dimensional ones, with potential for piezoelectric materials to function at large scales. This research aims to increase our use of ubiquitous ambient energy sources, such as vibrations in engines, roads, or buildings that are largely wasted today.

Broader Impacts
The integrated research and education plan will synergistically benefit society. Hands-on workshops in a summer camp will inspire interests in science, technology and engineering among K-12 students. The PI?s interdisciplinary research does not require advanced knowledge for students to begin, which will facilitate efforts to recruit underrepresented undergraduate students. The intrigued student can then gain unique experiences by assisting with the proposed research and relevant knowledge through a new course entitled ?Engineered Nanomaterials for Solid-State Energy Conversion?. The research result will be disseminated in leading journals, conferences, and workshops to benefit the scientific community and will be incorporated into the classroom to foster student learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated in-depth the energy conversion in nanomaterials and improved the power generation through materials improvement and device design. This project has also enabled high school students visiting labs and participating in other activities through summer camps and undergraduate students getting trained through conducting research works.

The growth of nanomaterials with controlled properties and aligning nanowires in a controlled manner is of importance for both fundamental study and practical application. A novel and scalable approach to align and transfer nanowires in a spinning Langmuir film has been discovered. The growth of well-aligned ZnO nanowire arrays was achieved through the new growth process combining the hydrothermal process and the vapor deposition process. Peptides are biomaterials consisting of amino acids like the well-known proteins. A new growth process was unveiled to produce piezoelectric peptide microrods with controlled polarization, which make the application of peptides as smart materials possible. Some other piezoelectric materials, such as P(VDF-TrFE), have also been studied, and valuable results have been achieved. Many devices have been developed through the project. In particular, the first peptide-based nanogenerator was fabricated and the performance exceeds similar devices based on other materials including ZnO and virus. The performance was further improved with the static charges accumulated on the surface.

The researchers attended numerous conferences and meeting and disseminate their finding through oral presentation and posters. For example, one researcher was invited to gave a tutorial for the 2017 MRS spring meeting at Phoenix, Arizona, so that the attending audience got to know more about energy harvesting through nanomaterials and nanotechnology.

Both graduate and undergraduate student were given the opportunity to get access to the state-of-the-art facilities. In particular, they are trained to use the facilities in Minnesota Nano Center, a site of the NSF-funded new National Nanotechnology Coordinated Infrastructure (NNCI). Students were also sent to attend professional conferences so that they can disseminate our research result, learn from others, and expand their network. Summer camps were hosted during the project. These high students have the opportunity to know the research frontier, play with the demonstration devices, and operate the scientific instrument. High school students’ interests in STEM got inspired in the summer camp and they will be potentially the future workforces in areas of STEM.
